results.title: The Flycycle
results.brief_description:
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2004.
An older, wiser man recalls his memories as a youth observing the fantastic efforts of his uncle to achieve a new form of flight.

results.title: Dog gone
results.brief_description:
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2004.
Sal completed Dog Gone as a student at AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT. Utilising two different animation techniques (clay and hand drawn), this work is a short fantasy tale about an old dog who runs away from home to learn a few new tricks.

results.title: Storm over Asia = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Set during the British occupation of Mongolia in 1920, this is the half heroic, half ironic story of Bair, a young Mongolian hunter-turned-partisan who is captured. A document in his possession identifies him as a descendent of Genghis Khan. The interventionists decide to ‘resurrect’ him as a puppet king. However Bair escapes and leads the Mongolian army against the interventionists. The intensity of the drama, strong feeling for landscape and dramatic use of montage (four or five times the usual number of shots for a feature of this length) have been compared with the work of D.W. Griffith. In effect, the film is one long chase which takes on mythic proportions while the plot takes on metaphoric and lyrical dimensions (the British army is literally ‘blown away’). The emotional impact disguises the methodological rigour of Pudovkin’s construction. Also known as The Descendant of Genghis Khan. Cast includes Valeri Inkizhinov. This fully restored and digitally remastered version contains an original score by Timothy Brock performed by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.

results.title: Mantis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “RMIT Collection”.
Enter the world of the insects to study a curious form of predatory behaviour. Mantis is a short computer animation utilizing sophisticated 3D techniques to create an immersive entomological environment in which we follow the misadventure of a praying mantis. During the animation the roles of “predator” and “victim” are switched to demonstrate how some animals must kill for survival while humans can kill for blatantly inconsequential reasons. Glenn Tracy is a graduate of the Advanced Diploma of Arts in Electronic Design & Interactive Media, Creative Media Department RMIT, Melbourne, Australia.

results.title: RMIT AIM Collection 1993
results.brief_description:
Compilation of student work from the University of RMIT Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) Department. 1993.
The Centre for Animation and Interactive Media, its courses, facilities, staff and collection of work was transferred from Swinburne University of Technology to RMIT University in 1995.

results.title: The Snow queen
results.creator_credit: Vladlen Barbe, Mark Buchwald, Igor Kostigin, Joshua M. Greene, Lightyear Entertainment and Klassika Studio Moscow
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Stories to remember”.
Sigourney Weaver narrates Andersen’s moving story of a young girl’s quest for her young friend who has been captured by the beautiful but heartless Snow Queen and taken to her icy palace far from humankind. Along the way she makes new friends who help her in her search. Based on Susan Jeffers’ illustrations for the picture book adaptation by Amy Ehrlich.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vladlen Barbe, Mark Buchwald, Igor Kostigin, Joshua M. Greene, Lightyear Entertainment and Klassika Studio Moscow

results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
